title: Italian aircraft carrier Giuseppe Garibaldi
text:
Giuseppe Garibaldi is an Italian <a href="aircraft%20carrier">aircraft carrier</a>, the first through deck aviation ship ever built for the <a href="Italian%20Navy">Italian Navy</a>, and the first Italian ship built to operate <a href="Carrier-based%20aircraft">fixed-wing aircraft</a>. She is equipped with <a href="STOVL">short take-off and vertical landing aircraft</a> (STOVL) aircraft and helicopters. "Giuseppe Garibaldi" was involved in combat air operations off <a href="Somalia">Somalia</a>, <a href="Kosovo">Kosovo</a>, <a href="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> and <a href="Libya">Libya</a>.
Design.
The "Giuseppe Garibaldi" is the fourth ship of the <a href="Italian%20Navy">Italian Navy</a> to be named after the 19th century Italian General <a href="Giuseppe%20Garibaldi">Giuseppe Garibaldi</a>. All four ships, including the missile cruiser, together with an image of Garibaldi, are depicted in the crest.
Built by <a href="Fincantieri">Fincantieri</a> (Italcantieri) at the <a href="Monfalcone">Monfalcone</a> shipyards on the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Trieste">Gulf of Trieste</a>, she was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 26 March 1981, <a href="Ship%20naming%20and%20launching">launched</a> on 11 June 1983, and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 30 September 1985. "Garibaldi" is classed as an <a href="anti-submarine%20warfare%20carrier">anti-submarine warfare carrier</a> (ASW), and is based in <a href="Taranto">Taranto</a>.
The ship is powered by four <a href="Fiat">Fiat</a> <a href="COGAG">COGAG</a> <a href="gas%20turbine">gas turbine</a>s built under license from <a href="General%20Electric">GE</a>, offering a sustained power of 81,000 hp (60 MW). Driving two shafts the ship has a maximum speed of and can travel for at around .
The ship was equipped with four <a href="Otomat">Otomat Mk2</a> short range <a href="surface-to-surface%20missile">surface-to-surface missile</a> system installed at the stern of the ship (removed in 2003 to improve the <a href="flight%20deck">flight deck</a> and <a href="satellite%20communication">satellite communication</a>s) and two ILAS three triple tube <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a> launchers. Defences are provided by two eight-cell <a href="Surface-to-air%20missile">SAM</a> launchers firing the <a href="SARH">SARH</a> "<a href="Aspide">Aspide</a>" missile, and three <a href="Oto%20Melara">Oto Melara</a> Twin 40L70 <a href="DARDO">DARDO</a> <a href="CIWS">CIWS</a>.
The ship also has many <a href="Electronic%20countermeasures">countermeasures</a> including two SCLAR twenty-barrel launchers for <a href="Chaff%20%28radar%20countermeasure%29">chaff</a>, <a href="decoy">decoy</a>, flares, or jammers, the <a href="SLQ-25%20Nixie">SLQ-25 Nixie</a> and SLAT anti-torpedo systems and <a href="Electronic%20countermeasures">ECM</a> systems.
The air arm consists of a maximum of sixteen <a href="McDonnell%20Douglas%20AV-8B%20Harrier%20II">AV-8B Harrier IIs</a> and two <a href="search%20and%20rescue">search and rescue</a> helicopters, or eighteen <a href="Agusta">Agusta helicopters</a> or a mix of helicopters and fighters. The flight deck is the characteristic off-axis design with a 6.5 degree <a href="Aircraft%20ski-jump">ski-jump</a> for <a href="STOL">STOL</a> aircraft; she is long and wide.
A 1937 law gave control of all national fixed-wing air assets to the <a href="Italian%20Air%20Force">Italian Air Force</a> and the navy was only permitted to operate helicopters. At the time of the ship's commissioning the "Garibaldi" the <a href="Italian%20Navy%20Aviation">Italian Navy Aviation</a> did not receive her Harriers so she was reclassified as an "Incrociatore portaeromobili" (Italian for "Aircraft carrying cruiser"). Until 1988 only Italian helicopters landed on her deck, as well as <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> Sea Harriers during NATO joint maneuvers. The ban on fixed-wing aircraft was lifted in 1989, and the Italian Navy acquired Harrier II fighters to fly from the "Giuseppe Garibaldi".
In 2009 "Giuseppe Garibaldi" was replaced as the flagship of the Italian navy by the new and larger carrier .
The ship underwent a modernization in 2003 and a major restructuring in 2013.
Combat operations.
In 1999 with the <a href="Kosovo%20War">Kosovo War</a> in the Balkans, Italy committed Harrier AV-8B II+ fighters embarked aboard "Giuseppe Garibaldi", from 13 May to early June 1999. The planes carried out 30 sorties in 63 hours of flight. The planes used Mk 82 GBU-16 bombs and AGM-65 Maverick missiles. The Italian naval force in addition to the aircraft carrier "Giuseppe Garibaldi", with her air group, included the .
Following the attacks of 11 September 2001 and the war on terror declared by U.S. President Bush, Italy participated in <a href="Participants%20in%20Operation%20Enduring%20Freedom">Operation Enduring Freedom</a> in Afghanistan. "Giuseppe Garibaldi" was engaged as the command ship of GRUPNAVIT I, 1 Italian Shipping Group, which also included "Zeffiro", the patrol team and the airman supplier in Etna. The group set sail from Taranto on 18 November 2001. They trained in the Indian Ocean from 3 December 2001 to 1 March 2002 and returned to Taranto 18 March 2002. During the mission, the AV-8B Harrier unit carried out 288 missions for a total of 860 hours of flight. Tasks carried out included interception/interdiction, sea and air support, and aircraft interdiction in Afghanistan.
Participating in the <a href="2011%20military%20intervention%20in%20Libya">2011 military intervention in Libya</a> after the transfer of authority to NATO and the decision to participate in strike air-ground operations, the Italian government assigned under NATO command four Italian Navy AV-8B plus (from Garibaldi) in addition to Italian air force aircraft. As of 24 March, the <a href="Italian%20Navy">Italian Navy</a> was engaged in <a href="Operation%20Unified%20Protector">Operation Unified Protector</a> with the light aircraft carrier "Garibaldi", the "Maestrale"-class frigate and the auxiliary ship . Additionally the and "Maestrale"-class frigate were patrolling off the <a href="Sicily">Sicilian</a> coast in an air-defence role. In total, until the end of the mission in Libya, the eight Italian Navy AV-8Bs flying from the carrier "Giuseppe Garibaldi" dropped 160 guided bombs during 1221 flight hours.
